Graphical abstract Deep eutectic solvents can play multifunctional roles in the realm of green hydrogen technologies, potentially elevating it to super green hydrogen. Further research is needed to accelerate development and advance the technology readiness level. While reliance on renewable energy resources has become a reality, there is still a need to deploy greener and more sustainable methods in order to achieve sustainable development goals. Indeed, green hydrogen is currently believed to be a reliable solution for global warming and the pollution challenges arising from fossil fuels, making it the resilient fuel of the future. However, the sustainability of green hydrogen technologies is yet to be achieved. In this context, generation of green hydrogen with the aid of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as green mixtures has been demonstrated as a promising research area. This systematic review article covers green hydrogen generation through water splitting and biomass fermentation when DESs are utilized within the generation process. It also discusses the incorporation of DESs in fuel cell technologies. DESs can play a variety of roles such as solvent, electrolyte, or precursor; colloidal suspension and reaction medium; galvanic replacement, shape-controlling, decoration, or extractive agent; finally oxidant. These roles are relevant to several methods of green hydrogen generation, including electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and fermentation. As such, it is of utmost importance to screen potential DES formulations and determine how they can function in and contribute throughout the green hydrogen mobility stages. The realization of super green hydrogen generation stands out as a pivotal milestone in our journey towards achieving a more sustainable form of development; DESs have great potential in making this milestone achievable. Overall, incorporating DESs in hydrogen generation constitutes a promising research area and offers potential scalability for green hydrogen production, storage, transport, and utilization. Keywords Water splitting Biohydrogen Super green hydrogen Electrocatalysis Photocatalysis Fuel cell Power-to-X 1 Introduction Due to the substantial depletion of conventional energy resources such as coal and petroleum products, there is a global momentum to seek alternative green, clean, and renewable resources. In the midst of this ever-evolving energy transition, the establishment of a knowledge-based and climate-neutral economy becomes paramount. However, achieving such an economy necessitates a dynamic transition in our strategies, with sustainability serving as the compass that guides our course and the metric by which we gauge our accomplishments in meeting the demands of the 21st century. The shift in research priorities entails both the development of Power-to-X technologies and the augmentation of energy efficiency. Recently, hydrogen has been acclaimed as a promising Power-to-X technology that serves a dual role, acting as both energy source and energy carrier, on account of its sustainability, high efficiency, and zero carbon emissions [1,2]. Among all elements in the periodic table, hydrogen is the lightest and smallest, with atomic mass 1.008 and Bohr atomic radius 52.947 pm. It is the most abundant element in universal settings [3,4]; for example, it can be found in large quantities in the sun, constituting 73.4% of stellar mass and being responsible for 85% of sun energy. On Earth, it is the tenth most abundant element (0.14%) and can be found in the atmosphere (0.6 ppm), in water, in organic molecules, and in other chemical compounds [5]. Hydrogen’s high energy density of 120 MJ kg−1 (i.e., three-fold the energy densities of gasoline and diesel, at 45.8 and 45.5 MJ kg−1 respectively) renders it superior to conventional fossil fuels [6–9]. Accordingly, hydrogen is currently under extensive global investigation as a potential future energy carrier. It is also recognized as a crucial foundational element for the essential transition to carbon–neutral energy in hard-to-abate sectors, the better to alleviate the impacts of global warming [10,11]. Global hydrogen production volume increased in the past couple of years, and the market is expected to further expand in the near future [12]. In 2021, global hydrogen production reached 94 million tonnes (Mt H2), alongside 900 Mt of emitted CO2. Notably, 62% of produced hydrogen was obtained from natural gas coupled with carbon capture, utilization, and storage, while 19% was produced from coal, and 18% as a by-product of naphtha reforming [13]. Produced hydrogen receives a color classification based on the production technology used; Fig. 1 depicts the main colors, of which the most common are grey, blue, and recently green hydrogen. Grey hydrogen is typically produced via petroleum and natural gas steam reforming, which is not a sustainable process in the long term. Blue and green denote cleaner hydrogen produced through alternative processes. The synthetic route of blue hydrogen is similar to that of grey hydrogen, but with the emitted CO2 being captured. Although this technology is acceptable and industrially implemented, it is nonetheless not an ideal solution to global warming nor for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and therefore, green hydrogen would be more superior to defossilize the energy sector. Other colors of hydrogen are produced from different processes and utilize different energy sources and feedstocks: black and brown hydrogen are produced via black and brown coal gasification; turquoise hydrogen is produced via pyrolysis with methane as the feedstock material; pink hydrogen is produced using nuclear energy in a process similar to that used for green hydrogen (i.e., via water splitting). It merits mention that there is apparently still some disagreement about and use of non-standardized color coding for hydrogen production routes [14,15]. For instance, red hydrogen is sometimes used in place of pink hydrogen. White hydrogen can refer to naturally-produced subsurface hydrogen, but some researchers denote that color for concentrated solar energy and thermochemical water splitting cycles. However, the latter can also be classified under green hydrogen, and therefore white hydrogen is best applied to the 'natural' and geologic production of hydrogen. Meanwhile, gold hydrogen was coined to reflect hydrogen produced in depleted oil by fermenting microbes found in wells, and may be applied to naturally-occurring hydrogen more broadly [15,16], similar to white hydrogen. Yellow hydrogen indicates production by electrolysis with fossil-fuel-based grid electricity; however, other colors are also used for the same source, such as purple and orange. At the same time, yellow is also used to indicate production through water splitting using solar energy, another route that can be classified as green hydrogen. Therefore, the usage of yellow to denote production using fossil fuel-based grid electricity would be more distinctive. Finally, aqua hydrogen was recently coined by Yu et al. to indicate hydrogen generated from oil sands oil fields with free carbon emissions [17], while aquamarine hydrogen indicates production by means of CH4 pyrolysis with a carbon catalyst and concentrated solar energy [18]. Minimizing the spectrum of color codes and other terminologies used to differentiate hydrogen production routes is highly recommended to avoid confusion in the literature and contradictory definitions. It is therefore imperative that standardization takes place. All of these different hydrogen production methods emit different amounts of CO2 (Table 1 ). Ultimately, there appears to be only one viable path forward for mankind, i.e., transitioning to green hydrogen as the most sustainable fuel. Green hydrogen can be produced from the most abundant resources on earth, water and biomass. Water splitting is viewed as the cleaner, greener, more sustainable, and more effective method; this approach relies upon water, a renewable energy source, and the presence of an electrocatalyst or photocatalyst. Production of green hydrogen from biomass occurs through fermentation, in which sugars are converted to bio-based fuels, including biohydrogen. However, there is not yet a consensus on the classification of this production route as green hydrogen [15]. That is, it is feasible to classify biomass hydrogen as ‘green’ so long as it is being generated from renewable feedstock and using renewable energy sources, but dark fermentation and microbial electrolysis cell methods might fail the second criterion, as they are light-independent [19]. Diverse forms of energy can be used to generate green hydrogen, namely heat, light, and electricity. Fig. 2 illustrates the various renewable energy sources, forms of energy, and renewable feedstocks used in producing green hydrogen. While biomass energy is considered renewable, it is carbon-emitting; therefore, to truly align with the concept of ‘green’ hydrogen, this energy source should be excluded. Nuclear is commonly reported as a ‘clean’ energy source; however, while free of carbon emissions, nuclear energy produces nuclear waste, cannot be counted as a naturally replenishing form of energy, and loss of control carries high risk in that any incident might be disastrous to the Earth and living organisms. Therefore, more eco-friendly renewable and non-carbon-emitting energy sources are of utmost importance in the realm of green hydrogen. Notably, while the various approaches for generating green hydrogen are lauded, there remains a key question to be asked: “Are the current green hydrogen technologies purely sustainable?” The answer should be No. Use of volatile organic compounds and other carbon-emitting agents renders the current technologies neither entirely sustainable nor entirely green. Moreover, this shortcoming will be intensified with the impending deployment of multi-terawatt electrolyzers. It is therefore imperative to utilize more environmentally-friendly agents and make current “green” hydrogen technologies greener and more sustainable. As mentioned earlier, green hydrogen is classified as such because it relies on renewable energy sources during production. Hydrogen produced with the greenification of both energy source and technology can thus be referred to as super green hydrogen, and represents the pinnacle of sustainability. In this context, deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have emerged as a new class of green designer multi-task agents. DESs can be prepared from natural metabolites and generally have distinctive physicochemical properties. Many recent studies have investigated their potential utility in application areas as diverse as nanotechnology [20–22], biotechnology [23], drug engineering [24–26], biomass processing [27,28], energy storage [29–35], oil and gas industry [36], and renewable energy technologies [31,37] including green hydrogen [2,38,39]. The aim of this review article is to provide an overview of the main roles of DESs in generating green hydrogen (Fig. 3 ). Studies have utilized DESs at a number of stages in hydrogen generation processes (e.g., catalyst preparation and biomass pretreatment); however, not all reported the rationale for utilizing a DES in a particular role. When reviewing such papers, discussion of green hydrogen was omitted and only the DES-relevant results were considered. Conversely, when authors connected the DES with overall green hydrogen generation efficiency, more details and insight were provided and hence included here. A number of published review articles have been dedicated to the applications of DESs in energy and renewable energy; however, these mainly tackled other applications such as solar energy [37,40], energy storage [31–33,41,42], and biofuels [28,43–49]. In addition, three review articles have discussed DES applications in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), but mainly concerned their electrocatalytic activity, primarily in electrochemical water splitting [2,38,50]. For example, Kityk et al. [50] recently published a review article dedicated to the use of DESs in electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting. In contrast to those publications, the main scope of the current article is to cover all DES roles implicated in green hydrogen generation technologies, namely water splitting via electrocatalysis and photocatalysis and biomass via fermentation. It also discusses the roles of DESs in hydrogen fuel cells. Therefore, this article acts as a compilation and a comprehensive reference of all green hydrogen generation and utilization technologies. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic review article to classify DESs based on their roles in this emerging research field. Accordingly, we also identify and thoroughly discuss current research gaps. The methodology used for this review was that of a systematic literature review: assessing and interpreting articles relevant to super green hydrogen production, and providing critical and subjective review. The PRISMA protocol was applied to ensure the selection of quality literature. Relevant literature was collected by means of search engines, Google Scholar, high impact journals, and the reference lists of published papers, and was categorized based on the green hydrogen production process utilized and the role of the investigated DES in enhancing production. The inclusion/exclusion criteria for articles are listed in Table S1. After identifying relevant papers, the important sections of the articles were reviewed thoroughly, and the main outcomes were highlighted and compared to those of other articles using tables, figures, and visuals. During this process, authoritative recommendations and perspective comments were recorded, as well as the limitations and challenges. Interestingly, we found that the terms “hydrogen generation” and “hydrogen production” are commonly used interchangeably. While these phrases seem quite similar, there is a subtle difference in connotation: hydrogen production indicates systematic, larger-scale generation, while hydrogen generation is more appropriate for lab-scale processes. In this review article, “hydrogen generation” is consistently used throughout, as all DES research pertaining to hydrogen is still in the initial technology readiness level (TRL). 2 Features of DESs Ionic liquids (ILs) are another solvent type that have been extensively investigated as replacements for organic liquids. ILs were viewed as a green alternative despite their questionable toxicity and biodegradability [51,52]; meanwhile, DESs have emerged as versatile substitutes for ILs, and indeed were initially referred to as a new class of ILs. DESs and ILs share similar physiochemical properties, but differ in some key aspects including cost, environmental impact, ease of preparation, and the type of intermolecular bonding. Additionally, DESs can be synthesized from natural metabolites, biodegradable materials, and non- or less-toxic compounds; moreover, they are designable agents. As such, their utilization can intensify the “greenness” of green hydrogen technologies. Several review articles have discussed the key differences between ILs and DESs [53–59], including some dedicated to extensive review of the primary properties and features of DESs. Herein, we discuss the most relevant physicochemical properties of DESs, namely density, viscosity, ionic conductivity, electrochemical activity, and surface tension. Density is often considered one of the main properties that determines the potential applications of a DES. At room temperature (i.e., 25 °C), a DES typically has greater density than water, ranging 1.0–1.3 g cm−3 [60], except for hydrophobic DESs, which have lower densities when compared to water [61]. According to recent research, the differences can be explained by hole theory [62], which suggests that DES density is mainly dependent on molecule organization and the availability of holes and vacancies within the mixture [63]. Additionally, Abbott et al. showed that the choice of hydrogen bond acceptor (HBA) and donor (HBD) and their molar ratio affect the density of the final homogenous mixture [62]. Moreover, DES density has been proven to be temperature dependent; that is, a linear decrease in density is noticed with temperature increase [58,64]. Another key property of a DES is its viscosity, which affects mass transportation within the mixture [65]. DESs are considered viscous at room temperature, with viscosities that can be higher than 100 mPa s [57,58]. These high values are attributed to the extensive intermolecular interaction between the HBA and HBD (i.e., the hydrogen bond network), which hinders mass transfer and is the reason behind the low mobility of free species within a DES mixture [59]. In general, DES viscosity is dependent on the chemical nature of the HBA and HBD and their molar ratio, as well as the free volume within the mixture; thus, hole theory is also applicable to the design of lower-viscosity DESs. Notably, low-viscosity DESs are preferable for use as green media. Viscosity is also affected by temperature, as higher temperatures can result in breaking of the hydrogen bonds between DES components, thereby lowering the viscosity of the entire mixture [57]. Conductivity is another crucial property that influences the utility of DESs, as it is a measure of mass transportation within the mixture [65]. Viscosity directly influences conductivity, and hence most DESs have poor conductivity, normally below 2 mS cm−1 at room temperature [58]. As with viscosity, conductivity is affected by temperature [65]; however, conductivity increases with increasing temperature. This is mainly because when the hydrogen bonds are broken, ionic mobility increases and hence more conductivity is developed [57]. Beyond conductivity, the electrochemical properties of DES are key considerations for their applications in energy devices. Generally, the electrochemical window (EW) of a DES can be used as an indication of its electrochemical stability [66,67]. The EW is the voltage gap between the cathodic and anodic limits [67]. Compared to an aqueous electrolyte, the EW of a DES is wider, which makes these mixtures attractive substitutes for aqueous electrolytes in energy storage devices [65]. In particular, DES electrical conductivity and electrochemical window have demonstrated promising results for battery and fuel cell applications [31,37,68], though there remains much ground still to be covered. The last key property is surface tension, which is relatively limited in DESs. Surface tension is an indicator of the intensity of the intermolecular forces between the HBA and HBD [58]. Applications that involve mixing, fluid flow, and separation normally require the surface tension be accurately quantified [69]. Similar to viscosity, higher temperature results in a reduction of surface tension due to the breaking of intermolecular forces [63,69]. Molecular liquids and ILs have been well explored in the literature, and therefore the databases of these molecules are sufficient and rich. By contrast, DESs have yet to be thoroughly characterized and thus their database is incomplete. In addition, many early concepts have been dramatically reshaped based on new findings. For example, it was initially claimed that DESs are non-toxic and biodegradable, being mainly prepared from natural or benign chief ingredients. However, these claims were refuted by Hayyan et al., who reported such generic statements to not be applicable to all DES formulations [70,71]. There remains much work to be done before judging how DESs as a class are superior to other ionic- and molecular-based agents. For instance, a number of essential features are yet to be fully elucidated, such as DES toxicity, biodegradability, biocompatibility, corrosivity, vapor pressure, volatility, flammability, long-term stability, and decomposition. Economic feasibility is another critical factor that requires attention [72]. Also, it is imperative to assess the holistic sustainability of DESs. Lifecycle assessment (LCA) would be the ideal toolbox for this purpose. Finally, some strategies that have been proposed for intensifying ‘greenness’ are applicable to both DESs and ILs [52]. As concerns the generation of green hydrogen using DESs specifically, and in light of the 12 Principles of Green Chemistry framework [73], the concept of sustainability can act as a roadmap. Table 2 outlines the key value chain strategies for designing effective DESs for energy and other applications. The primary framework elements are Synthesizable, Upgradable, Storable, and Treatable (SUST), and this framework is applicable to all possible roles that DESs can fill in green hydrogen production technologies, as well as a broader range of other applications. While these strategies seem challenging to attain, computational and artificial intelligence methods promise to be instrumental in significantly reducing time and cost. 3 Water splitting 3.1 Electrocatalysis of water (DES roles in electrocatalyst preparation) Water splitting via electrochemical reaction is viewed as a flexible and sustainable method for obtaining high-purity hydrogen. This mature process is based on employing a direct electric current to separate hydrogen and oxygen molecules, converting them into their gaseous states [74]. The hydrogen generated from this process can reach 99.999 vol.% purity once it has been dried, with no oxygen impurities [75]. Mechanistically, water electrolysis occurs when a direct electric current is circulated between two electrodes that are immersed in an electrolyte, which is necessary to enhance the ionic conductivity, since water itself is a poor conductor of electricity. Electrons flow from the outside circuit into the cathode and polarize it negatively, whereas the electrons leave the anode side, polarizing it positively. Thus, the reduction reaction occurs at the cathode, generating hydrogen, while the oxidation reaction takes place at the anode, generating oxygen. A diaphragm (i.e., separator) is required to prevent recombination of the hydrogen and oxygen molecules so generated. One of the main challenges in water electrolysis is the slow kinetics, which hinder industrialization of the process [38]. An excellent electrocatalyst is crucial for achieving high-efficiency catalysis of the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions (HER and OER) while avoiding environmental pollution [76]. Currently, materials based on noble metals, for example Pt, and Ir or Ru oxides are used as electrocatalysts to promote the HER; however, these materials suffer from prohibitive cost and scarcity [77–80]. Hence, development of electrocatalysts to enhance the HER in water splitting is considered a hot research area. In particular, a facile electrode fabrication method is highly desired for preparing electrodes that combine heterostructured electrocatalysts with porous substrates. Several approaches have been proposed in which DESs can be employed as the reaction medium, precursor, electrolyte, template, or other component. This section will mainly focus on the role of DESs in electrocatalyst preparation methods. 3.1.1 DESs as electrolytes in the electrochemical deposition process Electrochemical deposition, also known as electrodeposition, is one of the most widely-used methods for fabricating electrocatalysts. Electrochemical deposition is a readily accessible, affordable, versatile, and simple process that utilizes electrical current to deposit a thin layer of metal onto a surface (i.e., an electrode surface), with precise control over its composition, structure, surface characteristics, and electrocatalytic properties [81,82]. DESs feature outstanding attributes including a broad electrochemical window, excellent metal salt solubility, high electrical conductivity, and low vapor pressure; hence, they have been gaining considerable attention for utilization in electrochemical deposition. In particular, DESs have been proposed as electrolyte solutions, in which they offer advantages compared to aqueous solutions or ionic liquids; for instance, the presence of water does not negatively impact the properties of an electrocatalyst prepared through DES-aided electrochemical deposition. In addition, DESs are relatively inexpensive and regarded as biodegradable, although their actual biodegradability is still a matter of some debate [70]. As alternatives to precious metal catalysts, nickel and its alloys are considered viable because of their low cost, availability, and catalytic performance [83,84]. Many studies have investigated the ability of DES-based electrolytes to further elevate the performance of Ni-based electrocatalysts when used to mediate their preparation [38]. In this regard, Wang et al. [85] investigated the electrodeposition of nanostructured Ni films from NiCl2·6H2O as the Ni precursor, which was dissolved in two different DES-based electrolytes, choline chloride (ChCl) with urea (ChCl:urea) in a molar ratio of 1:2 and ChCl with ethylene glycol (ChCl:EG) in a molar ratio of 1:2. The electrochemical deposition process was performed in a three-electrode system with a Cu sheet as the working electrode, platinum flake as the counter, and Ag wire as the reference. A schematic representation of the electrochemical deposition process is given in Fig. 4 (a). After electrochemical deposition, the nanoscale morphology of the prepared Ni coatings was observed, revealing those produced in the ChCl:EG DES to feature smaller particles than coatings obtained from the ChCl:urea DES. Moreover, at an electrochemical deposition potential of −0.6 V, electrodeposits from ChCl:EG exhibited needle-shaped crystals of 30 nm in size, but as the electrochemical deposition potential reached −0.5 V, the deposited material took on a uniform spherical structure. This phenomenon was ascribed to the difference in electrochemical deposition potentials leading to morphology modifications. Additionally, the Ni films obtained from ChCl:EG had a thickness of about 0.7 µm, greater than the coatings obtained from ChCl:urea. These findings suggest that ChCl:EG is beneficial for Ni nucleation, likely due to its low viscosity. The prepared samples were subsequently used as working electrodes in another three-electrode system to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of Ni coatings prepared at different cathodic potentials (−0.6, −0.7, −0.8 and −0.9 V); the HER was carried out in an alkaline electrolyte, and the electrocatalytic activity of the coatings was evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry with a sweep rate of 1 mV s−1. The results revealed Ni-based electrodeposits from ChCl:EG obtained at a cathodic potential of −0.6 V to have higher catalytic activity towards HER due to their needle-shaped morphology providing a larger surface area. It is worth mention that this electrocatalyst showed the highest double-layer capacitance at 1.53 mF cm−2, a value seven times higher than commercially prepared Ni films (0.22 mF cm−2), further supporting that this electrocatalyst has a larger electrochemical surface area and therefore enhanced catalytic activity. However, the durability and stability of this catalyst yet require further improvement. In a separate study, Liu et al. [88] prepared Ni(OH)2/Ni on carbon felt electrodes using a ChCl:urea (1:2) DES mixed with nickel nitrate hexahydrate Ni(NO3)2.6H2O and different amounts of H2O (0 wt.%, 10 wt.%, and 20 wt.%). Investigation of the morphology of the prepared composite electrodes revealed larger particles in the electrode prepared in ChCl:urea +20 wt.% H2O, which resulted in uneven nanosheet deposition and an agglomerate layer with irregular sizes and shapes, thereby producing a rough surface. The other two electrodes exhibited similar morphologies comprised of many nanosheets and resulting in a porous structure; however, the electrocatalyst prepared in ChCl:urea +10 wt.% H2O presented a more uniform distribution of nanosheets and hence fewer nanosheet clusters than the electrocatalyst prepared in ChCl:urea alone. These results suggest that water might play an essential role in determining the crystal structure and morphology of these electrocatalysts. Ultimately, the electrocatalyst prepared from ChCl:urea +10 wt.% H2O was considered the most advantageous of the prepared samples due to its uniform and thin deposited layer allowing more rapid electron transportation between the carbon felt substrate and the electrocatalyst. Moreover, the addition of water in the electrolyte solution increased the number of active sites for both the HER and OER. Finally, the authors studied the electrocatalytic activity of the prepared electrocatalysts towards the HER in a three-electrode system using an alkaline electrolyte. As expected, the electrocatalyst prepared from ChCl:urea +10 wt.% H2O showed enhanced catalytic activity towards the OER and HER, with respective overpotentials of 192 mV and 564 mV at 100 mA cm−2; this better performance was due to the high electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) as well as the reduced resistance of the charge transfer that resulted from the hierarchical nanostructure. In another work, Protsenko et al. [82] examined the use of a ChCl:EG (1:2) DES as an electrochemical deposition electrolyte in conjunction with NiCl2·6H2O and different amounts of TiO2 nanopowder to fabricate Ni and Ni/TiO2. In this experiment, the composite coatings were grown on a gold plate substrate, and water was introduced to the electrolyte mixture to increase its conductivity and decrease its viscosity. The added water also increased the quantity of TiO2 particles embedded (from 2 wt.% to 10 wt.%). Based on data obtained from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray diffraction measurements and analysis, the authors speculated that the observed smoothing of the surface and reduction in crystalline size were attributable to adsorption of H2O molecules and TiO2 particulates on the surface of the growing Ni. That is, both H2O and TiO2 acted as specific surfactants that hindered the electrocyclization process, yielding consistent and smaller-grained coatings. When used to split water in a NaOH-water electrolyte system, the prepared Ni and Ni/TiO2 coatings on gold substrate showed enhanced electrocatalytic activity for the HER than conventionally prepared microcrystalline Ni layer. This performance was further improved when TiO2 particles were added into the nickel matrix, an effect that resulted from the existence of redox couples containing titanium on the coating surface. Ni-based bimetallic and multi-metallic catalysts prepared from DESs have recently gained considerable attention. These catalysts can be fabricated by adding another salt to a Ni-based system. In one example, Ni-Mo alloy microsphere films were grown on Cu foil by electrochemical deposition from ChCl:EG (1:2) mixed with NiCl2·6H2O, (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, and C6H8O7·H2O [86]. The prepared Ni-Mo-based electrode was then employed as a working electrode in an alkaline medium, where it displayed high efficiency, stability, and durability as an electrocatalyst for the HER and OER. These qualities can be attributed to the uncommon architecture of the porous microsphere, which contained small nanoparticles with extremely rough surfaces. Porosity provides more surface area and hence increases the availability of active sites for the electrocatalytic reaction; in addition, open channels facilitate electron/mass transportation and electrolyte penetration, allowing for fast reaction kinetics and gas release. In a second experiment, Ni-Mo-based electrodes were used as electrodes (both cathode and anode) in a two-electrode electrolyzer to investigate its performance towards water splitting in a KOH-based electrolyte. The results showed enhanced catalytic performance compared to Ni-based and Pt-based electrocatalysts, illustrated in Fig. 4(b). Notably, to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, a voltage of 1.59 V was required for the prepared bimetallic electrocatalyst, compared to over 1.85 and 1.55 V for the Ni-based and Pt-based electrocatalysts, respectively; thus, Ni-Mo catalytic activity surpasses that of Ni-centered bifunctional electrocatalysts. In work carried out by Zeng et al. [87], sulfur-doped Ni microsphere films on copper wire (NiS x /CW) were fabricated from NiCl2∙6H2O and thiourea as the Ni and S precursors, respectively, via one-step electrochemical deposition using a ChCl:EG (1:2) DES as the electrolyte. Introducing sulfur into the nickel system resulted in formation of cauliflower-like structures with improved HER catalytic activity (Fig. 4c). The improved catalytic activity can be linked to the strong electronic interaction between nickel networks and the incorporated sulfur atoms, alongside other factors. Several formulations were tested, of which Ni/S with atomic ratio 1:0.25 (NiS0.25) showed the highest electrocatalytic activity, achieving a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of −54 mV. Electrocatalyst stability was assessed by performing multiple cyclic voltammetry scanning at 0.20 and −0.20 V vs. reversible hydrogen evolution for over 6500 cycles with a sweep rate of 100 mV s−1; the results suggested NiS0.25 to have high stability for long-term electrolysis, with a stable current density. Several other experiments have applied the same approach to prepare bimetallic and multi-metallic electrocatalysts via electrochemical deposition from DES electrolytes, for example Ni-Mo [89], Ni-P [90,91], Ni-Cu [92], Ni-Ce [93], Ni-Fe [94], Ni-Co-Sn [95], Ni-Mo-Cu [96], Ni-Co-S [97], and Ni-Co-P [98] electrocatalysts. The results obtained are summarized in Table 3 . Beside nickel-based electrocatalysts, electrocatalysts based on transition metals such as cobalt, manganese, copper, and iron have also received great attention as means of enhancing the HER in electrocatalysis of water. Accordingly, many published studies have prepared transition-metal-based electrocatalysts by electrochemical deposition in a DES-based electrolyte. For instance, Li et al. [99] prepared P-Co nanoparticles grown in Ni foam (NF) via facile electrochemical deposition in ChCl:EG (1:2) mixed with CoCl2 and NaH2PO2. The preparation procedure is similar to that for Ni-based electrocatalysts; the only difference is the components added to the DES-based electrolyte. The authors then examined how electrocatalytic activity toward the HER and OER related to the ratio of P and Co content, charge transfer resistance, active sites, and morphology. The results proved that tuning P and Co contents results in well-distributed P-Co nanoparticles whose arrangement provides a large surface area and thereby improves the utilization of active sites, enhancing the HER and OER in an alkaline medium. Similarly, another study grew highly porous Co-S films in NF via electrodeposition in ChCl:EG (1:2) mixed with CoCl2 and 10, 30, 50, or 70 mM of thiourea as the Co and S precursors [105]. The prepared electrocatalysts were then used as working electrodes to evaluate their electrocatalytic activity towards the HER in KOH solution. The results revealed Co-S prepared with 50 mM thiourea to have superior performance for both the OER and HER; this was ascribed to the highly porous structure, which provided sufficient active sites and improved mass/gas transport. Other transition-metal-based catalysts that have been obtained from electrochemical deposition in DES-based electrolytes are presented in Table 3. Catalysts based on noble metals such as ruthenium (Ru) have also been studied for their use as electrocatalysts to enhance water splitting. These metals have remarkable electrochemical properties including corrosion resistance, good electrocatalytic activity, and high conductivity, which make them suitable for many industrial applications. Ru-based catalysts have been prepared by a number of methods, including sputtering, chemical vapor deposition, and atomic layer deposition; some of these methods require the use of toxic materials, spurring investigations into electrodeposition as an alternate approach for reason of its uncomplicated setup, affordability, and the capability to produce nanostructures of different morphology and porosity [114,115]. Application of DESs in the fabrication of Ru nanoparticles was first done in 2021 by Edison et al. [102], who electrodeposited Ru nanoparticles on a pre-treated stainless steel mesh in an electrolyte made of ChCl:urea (1:2) mixed with RuCl3 ⋅xH2O. The surface and electrochemical properties of the as-prepared electrocatalyst in an acidic medium (H2SO4) were then characterized, revealing a porous and rough surface with spherical-shaped nanoparticles of different sizes and enhanced electrocatalytic activity towards the HER when compared to Pt-based catalysts. Medina et al. [106] later synthesized palladium (Pd), rhodium (Rh), and PdRh nanoparticles on glassy carbon by electrochemical deposition in a DES-based electrolyte and examined their electrocatalytic performance toward the HER in an acidic medium. The DES used in the experiment was ChCl:urea (2:1) mixed with PdCl2, RhCl3, or PdCl2 + RhCl3 as precursors. The electrocatalytic evaluation employed linear sweep voltammetry, which found that Pd and Rh at respective potentials of 0.45 and −0.50 V exhibited higher activity than the PdRh-based catalyst. The better responses of those catalysts were mainly due to particle size and a crystalline plane arrangement, which lowered the energy required for hydrogen evolution. Overall, it is well-supported that the use of DESs as electrochemical deposition electrolytes produces electrocatalysts that offers enhanced activity towards the HER when compared to conventional Pt-based electrocatalysts. This enhancement is mainly connected to the improved structure and morphology of the prepared catalysts enhancing their overall catalytic activity. 3.1.2 DESs as galvanic replacement reaction agents The galvanic replacement reaction (GRR), also known as the galvanic displacement reaction, is a method of preparing metallic nanostructures. It involves a redox reaction where one metal displaces another in a compound or solution. Both the GRR and electrochemical deposition share the concept of species transfer; however, the GRR is a spontaneous reaction that occurs based on the reactivity of the involved metals, while electrochemical deposition is an electrochemical process driven by an external force, electric current. In the GRR, DESs are used as the reaction medium and combined with precursors of the desired electrocatalyst metal. The electrode (or substrate) containing the less reactive metal is immersed in the reaction medium, where that metal is replaced by the more reactive metal ions present in the medium. Employing DESs in the GRR helps provide a setting conducive to the formation of nanostructured materials by the nature of their particular properties, including surface tension, polarity, well-ordered hydrogen bonding network, and tunable redox properties [116–118]. As a case in point, Yang et al. [119] reported the growth of Ni3S2 films on a nanoporous copper (NPC) electrode, which served as a sacrificial template (i.e., reducing agent), using ChCl:EG (1:2) as the reaction medium. The NPC was simply immersed in the DES medium, which contained NiCl2·6H2O and 0.05 M thiourea as sources of Ni and S, respectively. The authors also fabricated other self-supported 3D nanostructured M-X (M = Ni or Co; X = S or P) electrodes using the same DES. The morphologies of the prepared electrodes were interestingly different; for instance, nanopores, nanorods, nanoflowers, and packed nanoparticles were obtained from Ni x P x , Co2P, Co9S8, and Co3S4, respectively. Driving forces of variation in nanostructures include variance in physiochemical characteristics, the nature of the active reaction components, and deposition kinetics. Subsequently, electrocatalytic performance measurements were carried out for prepared Ni3S2 in acidic (H2SO4), neutral (PBS), and alkaline (KOH) electrolytes. The results showed impressive HER activity in H2SO4 and KOH electrolytes, with respective Tafel slopes of 63.5 and 67.5 mV dec−1 and overpotentials of −91.6 and −60.8 mV when delivering a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Additionally, in a neutral electrolyte, the catalyst exhibited both super activity and stable performance, which can be attributed to synergy between Ni and S. In another study, Pd metal attached to nanoporous Ag substrate (Pd@NPA) was similarly developed via the GRR in a ChCl:EG (1:2) DES that contained PdCl2 as the Pd precursor [120]. Prior to the GRR process, the NPA substrate was synthesized via in-situ electrochemical alloying/dealloying, in which a ChCl:EG (1:2) DES containing ZnCl2 was used as the solvent to form an Ag-Zn alloy, and in-situ stripping was subsequently applied to extract the Zn component from the alloy surface to produce a 3D hierarchical NPA film. Following the GRR process, potential cycling activation was carried out to prepare the Pt-Pd@NPA catalyst (Fig. 5 a). Electrocatalyst structures with different Pd mass loadings were obtained by simply extending the reaction time (10 min, 0.5 h, 2.5 h, 5 h, and 10 h) (Fig. 5b). Interestingly, none of the prepared catalysts exhibited detachment (or peeling off) from the Ag substrate during bending tests, indicating excellent adhesion and mechanical robustness. Moreover, incorporation of Pd and Pt in the prepared substrate resulted in the creation of rougher skeletons with unutilized surface imperfections, which consequently enhanced electrocatalytic activity towards the HER. The authors assessed the electrocatalytic activity of an optimized Pt-Pd@NPA sample using linear sweep voltammetry in an acidic (H2SO4) electrolyte, which revealed enhanced catalytic activity with a Tafel slope of 31.2 mV dec−1. The sample’s HER performance was also evaluated in neutral (PBS) and alkaline (KOH) electrolytes, where it exhibited outstanding HER activity with respective Tafel slopes of 32.2 and 32.5 mV dec−1. The enhanced activity can be a result of the well-established structural integrity between the prepared catalyst and the substrate, a unique 3D interconnected nonporous structure that provided a large surface area and facilitated the transport of electrons and hydrogen gas in the electrolyte, and of a synergetic effect that lowered the energy barrier for hydrogen adsorption. In another study, ChCl:EG (1:2) containing a Ni precursor (NiCl2⋅6H2O) was utilized as a reaction medium to prepare nickel on a NPC template via the GRR [121]. The resulting catalyst displayed pronounced electrocatalytic activity for the HER in an alkaline electrolyte, with an overpotential of 170 mV being needed to deliver 10 mA cm−2; the Tafel slope of 98.5 mV dec−1 outperformed Tafel slopes reported for previous Ni-based catalysts for the HER. The results obtained from this and other above-described experiments are summarized in Table 4 . 3.1.3 DESs as precursors in pyrolysis Pyrolysis is another method commonly used to prepare electrocatalysts by transforming a precursor into a material with desired properties. DESs are proposed as precursors in the pyrolysis process, since they offer unique physiochemical properties and can be tuned according to product requirements. As a case in point, 2D nickel sulfide with graphene heterostructure (NiS/G) composites were fabricated via pyrolysis using a NiCl2⋅6H2O:polyethylene glycol 200 DES as the precursor [122]. Different amounts of polyethylene glycol 200 were tested; differential scanning calorimetry showed the DES with 1:4 molar ratio to exhibit the lowest melting point, and hence it was selected for preparing the desired electrocatalyst. Pyrolysis was performed by heating the DES in a furnace together with sublimed sulfur, which yielded the NiS/G composite. Field emission scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy were applied to characterize the microstructure of the prepared catalyst, and revealed a unique heterostructure that assisted the electronic interaction between NiS and graphene and produced more active sites. The prepared composite was then formulated into an ink by ultrasound-assisted suspension in deionized water and ethanol with Nafion solution. A carbon cloth (CC) covered by the prepared ink was then used as a working electrode in a three-electrode cell with an alkaline electrolyte to examine its electrocatalytic performance towards both the HER and the OER. The results revealed the prepared electrocatalyst to offer high electrocatalytic activity towards the HER, with a Tafel slope of 50.1 mV dec−1 and an overpotential of 70 mV at 10 mA cm−2, implying a rapid catalytic rate and high catalytic activity. A synergistic effect occurred between the NiS nanosheets and graphene ultrathin sheet, supporting the enhanced electrocatalytic activity. The kinetics of the electrocatalyst were then investigated using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, which revealed elevated electron conductivity due to coupling of graphene and NiS nanosheets. Additionally, an improved ECSA was observed, offering greater exposure of active sites. It should be noted that increasing or decreasing the polyethylene glycol 200 content resulted in lower catalytic activity; that is, the synthesis conditions significantly influenced the structure of the resulting catalyst and, consequently, its electrocatalytic activity. In another study, Ni2P/G was synthesized via pyrolysis using DESs composed of NiCl2⋅6H2O:malonic acid (molar ratios 1:3, 1:5, 1:7, and 1:9) [123], which were heated alongside NaH2PO2⋅2H2O until Ni2P/G was obtained (Fig. S1). The authors noted that the presence of a homogenous DES contributed to the formation of evenly distributed Ni2P/G. Similar to the previously discussed paper, CC covered with Ni2P/G was prepared and used as a working electrode with KOH as the electrolyte. Of the tested products, Ni2P/G prepared from NiCl2⋅6H2O:malonic acid (1:7) displayed the best catalytic performance for the HER, with a Tafel slope of 56.5 mV dec−1. Similar studies have employed the same approach to prepare NiS2 and 2D N-doped carbon/NiS2, from NiCl2⋅6H2O:malonic acid [124] and NiCl2⋅6H2O:urea [125] respectively. The results obtained are summarized in Table 5 . Li et al. [1] synthesized cobalt nanoparticles immobilized on nitrogen-doped porous carbon (Co@NPC) following the same procedure but with a ternary DES composed of ChCl:urea:gluconic acid as both precursor and self-template. Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O was added to the DES to achieve a well-dispersed precursor, which was then subjected to pyrolysis to obtain Co@NPC hybrids (Fig. S2a). When prepared at a reaction temperature of 800 °C, the obtained morphology consisted of cross-lined clusters, a consequence of the polycondensation processes of the DES. Subsequently, the prepared bifunctional electrocatalyst was used as a working electrode in a three-electrode cell, with the glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) as the process of choice in order to lower the overpotential for electrocatalytic hydrogen generation and preclude safety hazards that occur due to the presence of oxygen. Catalyst performance in the HER was also investigated in acidic and alkaline electrolyte systems, in which the overpotentials needed to deliver 10 mA cm−2 were respectively 215 and 274 mV, and the obtained Tafel slopes were 70 and 91 mV dec−1. Finally, the influence of DES composition on electrocatalytic activity towards the HER was evaluated in both electrolyte systems (Fig. S2b and c), with Co@NPC-1 denoting a binary DES composed of ChCl:urea and Co@NPC-2 a DES composed of ChCl:gluconic acid. All together, these results show that using a ternary DES in the preparation method can result in an electrocatalyst with enhanced activity in acidic and alkaline electrolytes compared to those produced using a binary DES. In another study carried out by Zhang et al. [127], nitrogen-doped carbon composite Co4N ultrathin nanosheets (Co4N/NC) were fabricated on CC via pyrolysis using a CoCl2⋅6H2O:urea DES. The molar ratio of the DES was first optimized, with a ratio of 1:12 showing the lowest melting point. The DES was then evenly applied on the CC surface and heated util Co4N/NC was obtained (Fig. S3a). The surface morphology of the synthesized electrocatalysts was examined using SEM and compared to that of pristine CC. It can be noticed in Fig. S3 (b) that the pristine CC has a smooth surface, whereas CCs with DES coatings exhibit a rough surface on which a uniform nanosheet has been grown due to the unique DES structure and its strong adhesion (Fig. S3c). Additionally, decomposition of urea during the pyrolysis process resulted in the release of CO2 and NH3 gases, which acted as exfoliation templates for the material and thereby supported formation of the ultra-thin nanosheet structure. The obtained Co4N/NC@CC was then used as a working electrode with KOH as the electrolyte. The overpotential obtained at 10 mA cm−2 current density was 62 mV, which is lower than the values from Co4N and CC electrodes and implies enhanced catalytic activity. In addition, the Tafel slope was 69.2 mV dec−1, indicating faster reaction kinetics than Co4N and CC. Further experiments were carried out in neutral and acidic electrolytes and supported the prepared electrode to have excellent catalytic activity, stability, and durability under a wide range of pH values. Similar preparation method was carried out to prepare various types of electrocatalysts, the results obtained are summarized in Table 5. 3.1.4 DESs as solvent and metal source in the sol–gel technique In a work carried out by Jaihindh et al. [130], ChCl:urea was used as a solvent and Cl− source to prepare Cl-doped CuO. NaOH was also introduced to the DES mixture alongside Cu(NO)3⋅3H2O as Cu precursor. After calcination for 2 h at 450 °C, the HER activity of the obtained Cl-doped CuO was investigated through linear sweep voltammetry; the results suggested enhanced HER activity of Cl-doped CuO produced using ChCl:urea (1.5:1), with an overpotential of 400 mV to deliver 10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 89 mV dec−1 indicating faster charge transfer kinetics. 3.1.5 DESs as precursors in phosphorization reactions Zhao et al. [131] synthesized a novel DES by mixing tetrabutylphosphonium chloride ([P4444]Cl; TBPC) with five other equimolar hydrated metal chlorides, namely FeCl3·6H2O, CoCl2·6H2O, NiCl2·6H2O, MnCl2·4H2O, and CrCl3·6H2O; this mixture was used as the HBA, with EG being used as the HBD. The DES obtained was then employed as a precursor in the synthesis of high-entropy metal phosphides (HEMPs) via one-step phosphorization under an inert atmosphere. Subsequently, the as-synthesized HEMP nanosheets were employed as electrocatalysts for cathodic and anodic water splitting in an alkaline-based cell, where they exhibited an overpotential of 136 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Interestingly, the melting point of the obtained DES was −68 °C, while those of EG and TBPC were −17 and 55 °C, respectively. Notably, this DES was prepared at room temperature without any need for a heat source, indicating that there is a potential subtopic to be explored in the preparation of DES mixtures. However, it remains advisable to screen the full spectrum of molar ratios and identify the eutectic point, which yields a full profile of the phase diagram. 3.1.6 DESs as solvent and colloidal suspension medium for synthesis of nanoparticles and nanocomposites In work carried out by Manikandan et al. [132], NiO nanocomposites were synthesized with activated carbon (AC) nanoparticles (NiO/AC) using a DES-based method. First, AC nanoflakes were derived from narthangai leaves and mixed with a solution of a ChCl:urea (1:2) DES, Ni(NO3)2, and NaOH under continuous stirring. The prepared solution was then washed and dried at a temperature of 70 °C, and afterwards subjected to annealing at 500 °C until NiO/AC nanopowder was obtained (Fig. S4). For comparison purposes, NiO was prepared following the same procedure without the addition of AC nanoflakes. The surface morphology of the prepared samples was characterized and their catalytic activity towards the HER was evaluated in an alkaline medium. The results generally suggested that addition of AC to NiO increases the ECSA (from 123 to 207 cm2), indicating enhanced catalytic behavior. Additionally, NiO/AC demonstrated lower overpotential due to having high conductivity and a high-porosity surface. 3.1.7 DESs as shape-controlling agents A study by Mohammadpour et al. [133] aimed to address the challenge of developing green, affordable, and high-yield exfoliation approaches by utilizing environmentally friendly solvents, namely DESs. In their experiment, a transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2) was prepared via solvent-assisted exfoliation/intercalation. It is worth noting that currently, transition metal dichalcogenides are prepared via a number of methods and approaches, including chemical vapor deposition, mechanical cleavage, and liquid-based synthesis. The last is the most favorable; however, it suffers from challenges associated with the utilization of organic solvents such as N-methylpyrrolidone or dimethylformamide, which leads to adverse environmental impacts. Therefore, Mohammadpour et al. used natural DESs (NADESs) as the reducing agents in MoS2 preparation. The NADESs that were tested, including amino acids, sugars, and organic acids, are listed in Table 6 . Of these NADESs, NADES 1, 3, and 4 demonstrated effective exfoliation of bulk MoS2 with high yield. However, only the MoS2 obtained from NADES 1 was further characterized, including for nanosheet stability. It is notable that the nanosheets were surprisingly stable against aggregation over time in aqueous solutions and in intricate cell culture media, even in the absence of any stabilizing agent or additive, due to the presence of negative residues on the metallic domains rendering the nanosheets hydrophilic in nature, and also to adsorption of NADES residues on the nanosheet surface. Interestingly, the authors explained the exfoliation mechanism for NADES 1, 2, 3 and 4, which all contained sucrose; these NADESs were observed to form larger solvent clusters through hydrogen bonding due to the larger size of sucrose molecules in comparison to fructose and glucose. NADES 5, 6, 7, and 8 were also tested as intercalating solvents, in which role only NADES 7 proved effective. Although NADES 7 was able to exfoliate MoS2, the obtained nanosheets were thick and their stability was limited. Finally, the authors investigated the electrochemical activity towards the HER of nanosheets produced from NADES 1, which exhibited a low onset overpotential and high durability in an acidic media. These results and their comparison to previously reported results are presented in Table S2. As a final note, some of the investigated NADES were aqueous; it has been reported that aqueous DESs might be less biodegradable compared to pure DESs [70]. Accordingly, it may not be appropriate to take as a general expectation that these NADES are environmentally friendly, without empirical verification. 3.1.8 DESs as treatment agents in electrocatalyst preparation In a work published recently by Mirshokraee et al. [134], a DES composed of ChCl:citric acid in a molar ratio of 1:1 was used to recycle a lithium cobalt oxide (LCO) cathode from a spent lithium ion battery. The LCO was directly extracted from the cathode waste and treated in the DES mixture via a leaching process. Subsequently, the material was heated to 350 °C to degrade the DES, resulting in the formation of crystalline/amorphous cobalt oxides supported on a carbon matrix (ChCl.Citric). The authors then used the obtained ChCl.Citric as an electrocatalyst and performed electrochemical analysis, including the HER and OER. It is worth noting that the authors mixed the electrocatalyst with conductive carbon black support in two proportions (10:90 and 50:50), aiming to reduce the actual cobalt content in the operating electrocatalyst while maintaining high electrocatalytic activity and thereby enhancing the overall valorization of the waste. Interestingly, the electrocatalyst with no conductive carbon black support exhibited an electrocatalytic activity similar to commercially purchased LCO, while electrocatalysts mixed with conductive carbon black in 50:50 and 10:90 ratios displayed respective overpotentials of 352 and 472 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Finally, untreated LCO mixed with conductive carbon black support showed good electrocatalytic activity with an overpotential of 277 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which was attributed to the presence of multiple cobalt-based species. 3.1.9 DESs as solvents for anodic treatment In another work carried out by Protsenko et al. [135], a ChCl:EG (1:2) DES was used for anodic surface treatment of Ni-Cu alloy (45 wt.% Ni). Under anodic surface salt passivation in the DES, sparingly soluble NiCl2 and CuCl2 formation was observed near the interface of the electrode layer. Prolonged anodic treatment with the DES significantly enhanced the surface morphology patterns while maintaining the chemical composition of the metallic surface layer; accordingly, the HER electrocatalytic activity of the treated Ni-Cu alloy was improved. A DES would therefore be superior to aqueous solutions in the anodic treatment processes, making this approach more convenient and feasible. 3.2 Urea-assisted water electrocatalysis 3.2.1 DESs as electrolytes in electrocatalyst preparation Much as for the water electrocatalysis process, DESs are proposed for use as electrodeposition electrolytes to prepare electrocatalysts used in urea-assisted water electrocatalysis. In work carried out by Sun et al. [136], ChCl:EG (1:2) was used as the electrodeposition electrolyte to fabricate Co x -Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles and Ni(OH)2 on Cu foam (CF) substrate via electrodeposition. The procedure was similar to that discussed in Section 3.1.1. The obtained electrocatalyst was then used as a working electrode in a three-electrode cell immersed in 1.0 M KOH with and without 0.5 M urea to evaluate hydrogen generation. Overall, the results revealed a superior electrocatalytic performance for Co0.26-Ni(OH)2/CF compared to bare Cu foam and Ni(OH)2/CF working electrodes, with a Tafel slope of 98.2 mV dec−1 and an overpotential of 106 mV to attain 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6 a). Only a negligible shift was observed when urea was added. Subsequently, water and urea electrolyzers were constructed to evaluate the catalytic activity of Co0.26-Ni(OH)2/CF when used as electrode material; this evaluation revealed urea electrocatalysis to result in more favorable thermodynamic and reaction kinetics than water electrocatalysis. Additionally, at a fixed voltage of 1.80 V, the hydrogen production rate was roughly 2.85 times higher in the urea electrolyzer (109 µL min−1) than the water electrolyzer (38.2 µL min−1). This was mainly ascribed to the presence of urea in the electrolyzer system (Fig. 6b). However, there remains a need to more fully elucidate how a DES impacts the efficacy and relative favor of different electrocatalytic processes. 3.2.2 DESs as medium, oxidant, and precursor in electrocatalyst preparation In a study carried out by Zhang et al., a DES composed of FeCl3.6H2 and urea as the HBA and HBD, respectively, in a molar ratio of 2:1 was used as a source of iron, an oxidant, and the medium for the preparation of NiFe layered double hydroxide (NiFe/LDH) via a dipping-redox strategy [137]. When NF was soaked in the as-prepared DES, three reactions occurred in series: urea hydrolysis, then a redox reaction between iron ions and the NF, and finally the formation of nanoflower-shaped NiFe/LDH. Sample characterization revealed a 3D flowerlike architecture with smooth nanosheets inside each nanoflower; moreover, the distribution of the nanostructure on the NF was uniform and ordered. To further verify the effect of the DES on NiFe/LDH morphology and properties, another sample was prepared using an aqueous solution of FeCl3 and likewise characterized. The aqueous-based sample exhibited irregular nanoflower shapes, along with differences in properties such as mass loading and NF corrosion degree. These differences were speculated to stem from the differing viscosity of the two mediums and the state of iron ions (i.e., whether combined or free). The more viscous DES inhibited the diffusion of metal ions, providing ample time for the formation of a uniform structure. Next, electrochemical measurements were performed in an alkaline medium using NiFe/LDH as both the cathode and anode in a two-electrode cell; this revealed the addition of urea to enhance catalytic activity, necessitating a cell voltage of 1.52 V to attain a current density of 10 mA cm−2. 3.3 Photocatalysis of water Heterogeneous photolysis follows the same approach as the electrolysis of water; however, this process utilizes solar energy to generate hydrogen and is known to be a more environmentally friendly route for water splitting [138]. Generation of hydrogen via photolysis can be done in the presence of a photocatalyst, in which case it is referred to as photocatalysis. The photocatalyst most commonly used in this process is titanium dioxide (TiO2) on account of its excellent properties including chemical stability, photo-corrosion resistance, and nontoxicity; however, it suffers from low photocatalytic activity as photogenerated charge carriers can easily recombine at its surface. Photocatalytic efficiency can be enhanced through modulating the electronic band structure using light-absorbing catalysts and by altering photocatalyst properties; accordingly, the fabrication of new photocatalysts with better overall photocatalysis process efficiency has become a priority. However, another challenge this process faces is the presence of oxygen, both that which is already ubiquitous in the air and that generated during splitting; oxygen is known to interfere with the generation of hydrogen, and it can inhibit and degrade the catalyst. Therefore, researchers have also been investigating solvents that can tolerate the presence of oxygen during water photocatalysis. DESs are proposed as solvents, reaction mediums, templates, inhibitors, precursors, and crystalline phase control agents to enhance hydrogen generation from photocatalysis. 3.3.1 DESs as reaction media In a study performed by Allan et al. [139], DESs were proposed as reaction media to enhance oxygen tolerance and thereby intensify hydrogen generation. This process incorporated free-catalysis modification and did not influence the overall quantum. Three DES systems were investigated, namely ChCl:urea (1:2), ChCl with glycerol (Gly) (1:2), and ChCl:EG (1:2), and the photocatalyst Pt/NCNCN x was evaluated for activity in water and in the DES media in air. In water, only 0.8 ± 0.2 mmolH2 gCNx −1 h−1 was observed (Fig. 7 a), corresponding to only 8.8 ± 1.5% of the photocatalytic activity in an anaerobic environment; meanwhile, in ChCl:urea, up to 8.7 ± 0.9 mmolH2 gCNx −1 h−1 was observed, a remarkable activity retention of 97.3 ± 17.5% without any modification of the photocatalyst (Fig. 7b). Moreover, in water, the O2 tolerance was observed to decrease after 10 h, while in the DES, a significant degree of O2 tolerance was maintained over a longer period of time. Fig. 7(c) shows the hydrogen evolved under aerobic and anaerobic environments in various reaction mediums, while Fig. 7(d) illustrates the O2 tolerance of different DES systems and water when using the Pt/NCNCN x photocatalyst in an aerobic condition. The authors additionally tested Pt/TiO2, Pt/NCNCN x , and homogeneous Pt/Eosin Y photocatalysts in water, ChCl:urea, and ChCl:EG; the results were generally similar, save that with the homogeneous photocatalyst, HER kinetics were slower in the DES than in water. This was ascribed to non-optimized conditions. More experimentation is required to optimize conditions and verify the observed HER kinetics. The above authors further developed a mechanistic model to quantify O2 tolerance and used a quantitative approach to infer a proposed mechanism. They speculated that O2 tolerance is a function of the O2 concentration at the surface of the photocatalyst. As O2 reduction proceeds, the amount of O2 in the DES is diminished; hence, reaching a steady-state O2 concentration at the catalyst surface is contingent on the rate at which surplus O2 is fed to the photocatalyst. O2 tolerance is also dependent on O2 solubility and diffusivity in the reaction medium. Analyzing the trends of these parameters in DES-based solutions in comparison to the trend in O2 tolerance reveals a distinct correlation, indicating clear connections with sustained retention of photocatalytic activity in the presence of air (glyceline ≈ reline > ethaline > water) and with O2 diffusivity (glyceline < reline < ethaline < water); notably, the O2 tolerances of glyceline and reline were comparable in spite of differing O2 solubility and diffusivity. Interestingly, the combined low diffusivity (primary) and solubility (secondary) of O2 in DESs can promote pseudo-inert conditions, thus limiting O2 mass transport and allowing diffusion of H+ to surpass it. By contrast, water exhibited low O2 tolerance due to its high O2 diffusivity and relatively high O2 solubility. The same group investigated the use of natural hydrogenase enzymes (i.e., [NiFeSe] hydrogenase) as co-catalysts with the photocatalyst TiO2 [140]. It is worth mentioning that hydrogenases experience a partial and reversible reduction in catalytic activity when employed in the presence of oxygen. The main aim of the experiment was to carry out solvent engineering to prepare [NiFeSe] from Desulfomicrobium baculatum (Db) with TiO2 in DES-water systems. Surprisingly, the DES was the first organic medium where [NiFeSe] hydrogenase was demonstrated to function for the HER. The DESs utilized in the experiment were ChCl:Gly (1:2) and ChCl:EG (1:2) mixed with triethanolamine (TEOA), which acts as an electron donor. The fabricated samples were exposed to simulated solar light at a temperature of 40 °C in an inert environment, and the hydrogen generated was measured using gas chromatography. Photocatalytic HER was observed in all samples, indicating that utilizing a DES as the reaction medium allowed Db[NiFeSe] to retain its catalytic HER activity. In solutions containing the ChCl:Gly DES, hydrogen generation was sustained for >24 h; comparable results were obtained when using ChCl:EG. Notably, compared to purely aqueous medium under the same conditions, the activity was enhanced by ∼19% when using 20 vol% ChCl:Gly. The authors further subjected the system with 20 vol% ChCl:Gly to a continuous purge of O2 to evaluate the O2 tolerance and stability of Db[NiFeSe] in relation to DES content (Fig. 7e). At higher DES content, high O2 tolerance was observed without any modifications to the photocatalyst (or the enzyme); this finding is similar to their previous study, in that DES presence contributes to O2 tolerance and favors the HER. The above-described reports clearly indicate the synergy of using DESs as multi-task agents to stabilize enzymes and photocatalyze the HER. However, it is highly recommended that further research investigate the activity and stability of these enzymes in association with DESs. For more insight into enzymatic applications using DESs, please refer to these review articles [23,141]. 3.3.2 DESs roles in photocatalyst preparation 3.3.2.1 DESs as solvents In work by Wang et al. [142], a DES composed of 1,5-diazabicyclo [5.4.0]-5-undecene (DBU) and N-methylthiourea as the HBA and HBD, respectively, was utilized as a solvent to dissolve nine V2VI3 bulk chalcogenides. After annealing, antimony- and bismuth-based pure materials were recovered as small-sized nanoparticles (diameter: 4–8 nm) with uniform and compact structures indicative of a wider band gap, which is favorable for photocatalysis of water (Fig. S5). Accordingly, the recovered films were used as photocatalysts with water as the solvent and visible light as the driving force. 3.3.2.2 DESs as solvents and decoration agents Mohite et al. [143] used a DES-assisted green synthesis process to prepare mono-sized Cu2O nanoclusters on the surface of TiO2 photocatalysts in order to improve photocatalytic activity for hydrogen generation. A ChCl:urea DES in a molar ratio of 1:2 was used as a solvent to decorate the Cu2O clusters. Specifically, Co(NO3)2⋅xH2O was dissolved in the prepared DES, and TiO2 nanoparticles were dispersed in deionized water and then introduced to the DES mixture to obtain Cu2O/TiO2 (Fig. S6). The synthesis process began with decomposition of urea, releasing NH3 into the reaction bath (Eq. (1)) that then directly reacted with Co(NO3)2 in the DES to form Co(NH3)(NO3)2 (Eq. (2)), which subsequently reacted with the water to form Cu2O derivatives (Eq. (3)) that were ultimately deposited on the TiO2 surface. The presence of the DES assisted in controlling the size of the clusters grown on the TiO2 nanoparticles. Varying the amount of Co(NO3)2⋅xH2O (10, 20, and 40 mg) in the DES mixture also affected nanocluster size (1.2, ∼1.5, and 2.0 nm, respectively) as well as the cluster distribution. The decorated Cu2O was able to minimize the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers and improved transfer of these charges, thereby enhancing overall photocatalytic activity. When the prepared photocatalysts were applied in hydrogen generation via water reduction, the DES-based photocatalyst with 1.5 nm nanoclusters yielded 24.21 mmol g−1 h−1, the highest production rate among tested photocatalysts. However, the thermal stability of the DES was not verified, and it is questionable that at 75 °C urea was the only compound undergoing decomposition in the DES mixture [144], given that this temperature is relatively close to the temperature of DES synthesis (60 °C). (1) CO ( NH 2 ) 2 → NH 3 + HCNO (2) C u ( N O 3 ) 2 + N H 3 → C u ( N H 3 ) ( N O 3 ) 2 (3) C u ( N H 3 ) ( N O 3 ) 2 + H 2 O → C u x O + 2 H N O 3 + N H 3 3.3.2.3 DESs as precursors Another type of photocatalyst that has been prepared using DESs is graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [145]. Such photocatalysts were originally developed as organic polymeric semiconductors and are known for their simple synthesis process, impressive thermochemical durability, and attractive electronic band arrangement. In the reviewed study, DESs were prepared from urea and ammonium thiocyanate (AT) in mass ratios of 1:2 and 2:1 and used as precursors to fabricate well-organized coralloid g-C3N4 stacked in double-layer g-C3N4/g-C3N4 nanocages (CN1U2AT and CN2U1AT, respectively). Both DESs were calcined at a temperature of 550 °C in air for 120 min to obtain yellow powders that were then dispersed in TEOA and used as photocatalysts. The g-C3N4 morphology prepared from urea:AT (2:1) is illustrated in Fig. 8 (a and b). The performance of the prepared g-C3N4 was assessed by the HER using Pt as a co-catalyst and compared against pristine g-C3N4, CNU, and CNUAT respectively prepared via thermal polymerization from melamine, urea, and AT precursors, as well as against commercial TiO2 (P25). When using CNU and CNUAT, only limited generation was obtained (Fig. 8c); the highest rate was obtained with CN2U1AT (3622 µmol g−1 catalyst h−1). This was ascribed to the greater number of catalytically active sites, high pore size, and distinct morphology of the prepared photocatalyst, which weakened the recombination of photogenerated carriers on its surface. 3.3.2.4 DESs as simultaneous solvent, inhibitor, template, and crystalline phase control agent Wang et al. [146] prepared for the first time phase-junction TiO2 using a DES as a solvent, inhibitor, template, and crystalline phase control agent all at the same time. The DES consisted of ChCl/betaine:oxalic acid at a molar ratio of 1:1, with the molar ratio of the two HBAs (ChCl/betaine) ranging from 1:6 to 6:1. Tetrabutyl titanate was then added to the DES mixture to obtain TiO2. Samples with a ChCl/betaine ratio of 1:6 formed microspheres through the aggregation of needle-shaped nanoparticles, while ratios of 1:3 to 1:1 resulted in needle-like nanoparticles, microspheres, and clusters. At a molar ratio of 2:1, microspheres of consistent size and even dispersion were constructed from thin needle-shaped nanoparticles. The catalytic activity of the prepared TiO2 was tested and compared to commercial TiO2; the results showed a 20-fold enhancement in the hydrogen production rate (14.51 mmol h−1 g−1) for the phase-junction TiO2. This represents the highest reported value for photocatalytic H2 generation using TiO2 as the catalyst. The authors attributed the enhanced rate to the phase junctions and defects that resulted from dislocation and disorder of the lattice within the catalyst. The same group also utilized a ChCl:oxalic acid DES as a solvent, template, and inhibitor to prepare TiO2 [147]. The resulting TiO2 had a Crassula peforata-like shape with consistent size and excellent dispersion. In addition to oxalic acid, several other HBDs (EG, glycerinum, and urea) were used alongside ChCl as the HBA, and structure of the different synthesized TiO2 samples was examined. Using EG, glycerinum, urea, and oxalic acid as the HBD respectively resulted in microrods, quasi-microspheres, microspheres, and quasi-Crassula peforata shapes. Similarly, tests using different HBAs (acetyl ChCl, betaine, and ChCl) alongside oxalic acid resulted in different TiO2 morphologies (microspheres, quasi-peanuts, and quasi-Crassula peforata, respectively). These results prove that both the HBA and the HBD used in the preparation method can significantly influence the final morphology of a prepared photocatalyst and hence its photocatalytic activity. Additionally, the results suggest that the hydrogen bond network between the HBA and HBD allows the DES to act as a template agent. Finally, the DES more strongly affected TiO2 size than did its individual ingredients and corresponding physical mixture, indicating that the DES acted as an inhibitor. 4 Fermentation Compared to conventional hydrogen generation routes, the biological route is considered more sustainable and environmentally friendly. In this route, biohydrogen is generated through a process of biomass treatment, enzymatic hydrolysis to sugars, and finally conversion of those biochemical sugars to biohydrogen (Fig. S7). Lignocellulosic biomass is an abundant waste material and renewable substrate that can be used for biohydrogen generation. However, the lignin and hemicellulose in such biomass act as a physical barrier that prevents enzymes from accessing the hydrolyzed cellulose and hence reduces the hydrolysis efficiency. To effectively break down the lignocellulosic recalcitrance and enable efficient fractionation, it is essential to remove lignin and hemicellulose via pretreatment. DESs have been proposed for use as agents in this pretreatment process. The following subsections discuss studies relevant to biohydrogen in which DESs were screened. 4.1 DESs for biomass pretreatment In work performed by Jing et al. [148], an acid DES of ChCl:ethanolamine in a molar ratio of 1:6 was utilized as a pretreatment agent for corncob biomass. Pretreatment was carried out by adding corncobs to the DES in a liquid:solid ratio (DES:corncob, g/g) of 10, 15, 20, 25, or 30:1 and continuously stirring for 12 h at a temperature of 50 °C. Following this treatment, the lignin and hemicellulose contents in corncobs respectively decreased from 28.54% to 18.79% and from 13.91% to 3.58%. These significant reductions were ascribed to the hydrogen bonding interaction between chloride ions and carbohydrate hydroxyl groups, which led to disruption of the existing bonds in lignocelluloses and promoted the extraction of hemicellulose and lignin. When increasing the ratio from 25:1 to 30:1, slightly less delignification efficiency was obtained (i.e., from 83.12% to 82.99%), indicating 25:1 as the best ratio for corncob pretreatment. Enzymatic hydrolysis was then carried out on the pretreated corncob to break it down to glucose and xylose. The concentration of reducing sugars in pretreated samples varied from 33.89 to 53.91 g L−1, but were consistently higher than in untreated corncob (7.92 g L−1). It is worth noting that a liquid to solid ratio of 25:1 yielded the highest concentration of reducing sugars at 53.91 g L−1, which is approximately 6.8 times greater than the concentration obtained from untreated corncob. Finally, biohydrogen generation was carried out; both the maximum production rate (15.8 mL h−1) and the maximum cumulative hydrogen yield (755 mL) were obtained from corncob pretreated with the DES at 25:1 (Fig. 9 a). This maximum cumulative value was 3.1 times higher than that obtained from untreated corncob. It was observed that as the liquid-to-solid ratio of DES-pretreated corncob increased, the cumulative biohydrogen yield also increased; moreover, production only started increasing after 12 h, with the initial low rate being ascribed to consumption of reducing sugars by photosynthetic bacteria during their growth phase. After exiting the growth phase, the reducing sugars were used to generate biohydrogen via nitrogenase metabolism (Fig. 9b). After 84 h, the production rate began decreasing due to the low pH level that resulted from the biohydrogen process and the harsh living environment. In a similar work, the same DES was utilized as a corncob pretreatment agent [149]. The maximum cumulative biohydrogen yield obtained was 677.45 mL (136 mL g−1) when the pretreatment process was carried out at 50 °C and for 12 h, 2.72 times higher than that obtained from untreated corncob. In another study, Chen et al. [150] developed a strategy in which they employed an AlCl3-assisted aqueous DES as a pretreatment agent to enhance the enzymatic hydrolysis process and subsequent production of biohydrogen from corn straw. The DES was comprised of ChCl and glycerol (Gly) in a molar ratio of 1:2 with 20% deionized water. Similar to the previous study, the pretreatment process consisted of adding 4.0 g of corn straw and 2.0 wt.% AlCl3 into the DES with magnetic stirring and was compared against a parallel AlCl3-free treatment. The results showed that incorporating AlCl3 enhanced lignin removal, increasing the removed portion from 35.3% to 57.9%. Similar results were obtained for hemicellulose content. The surface structure of the prepared samples was noticed to be rougher, accompanied by a notable absence of fibers, suggesting the effective removal of non-cellulosic elements. The presence of fibers enhanced the bio-accessibility of the pretreated samples, preparing them for the subsequent enzymatic saccharification. The enzymatic hydrolysis efficiency, a quantitative measure reflecting successful conversion of complex carbohydrates into sugars via enzymatic saccharification, was 75.0%–87.0% for AlCl3-pretreated samples, versus 31.8%–39.2% when using the AlCl3-free DES (Fig. 9c), indicating that addition of AlCl3 to the DES system could considerably enhance enzymatic efficiency. The carbohydrates in the resulting saccharification mixture were used as carbon sources by microorganisms to generate biohydrogen. After processing at 100 °C for 5 h, cumulative biohydrogen yields were significantly higher for AlCl3-pretreated samples (up to 114.8 mL g−1) than AlCl3-free samples (Fig. 9d). Additionally, glucose consumption for all tested samples was ∼90% after 84 h of fermentation.
