This proves that AlCl3 addition does not inhibit biohydrogen generation and can significantly enhance the generation efficiency. Interestingly, the generation period was shorter (12–24 h) for AlCl3-pretreated samples compared to AlCl3-free samples (24–36 h). This can be explained by the degree of non-cellulosic component removal in the earlier steps. Similar work was carried out where corn straw was pretreated using a DES composed of ChCl:1,4-butanediol in a molar ratio of 1:2 mixed with 80 wt.% deionized water to form an aqueous DES [151]. Four grams of corn straw was added to the prepared DES, with NaOH or AlCl3 also added to act as catalysts. The solid residues obtained after filtration were then hydrolyzed. The results suggested that addition of NaOH or AlCl3 caused more biomass components to be dissolved. Furthermore, with aid of these catalysts, effective removal of lignin from the corn straw was attained, with lignin content dropping from 18.8% to 7.3% and 9.9% respectively when processed with NaOH and AlCl3 at 4.0 wt.%. This enhanced removal can be attributed to 1,4-butanediol acting as a bridge, leading to the formation of a system with chlorine ions, 1,4-butanediol, and metal cations when AlCl3 was introduced. This system improved the reactivity of the DES. Generally, the results proved that AlCl3/NaOH-aided DES pretreatment systems are capable of removing more lignin and hence promoting enzymatic hydrolysis and subsequent biohydrogen production. Using the DES alone gave a biohydrogen yield of 39.9 mL g−1, versus 100.5 mL g−1 when also using 4.0 wt.% AlCl3 and 117.4 mL g−1 with 4.0 wt.% NaOH. Nevertheless, it is important to highlight that biohydrogen production in the NaOH-aided DES samples took place approximately 12 h later compared to the AlCl3-aided DES samples. Therefore, the addition of NaOH improved the amount of biohydrogen produced yet delayed completion of the fermentation process. Miftah et al. [152] evaluated the use of DESs in pretreatment of sugarcane leaves followed by a two-stage process of generating hydrogen and methane via anaerobic digestion. Three types of DESs were prepared (Table S3), and the effects of DES molar ratio, time, temperature and substrate to DES solution ratio on the pretreatment process were investigated. Among the various molar ratios tested, ChCl:MEA (1:6), ChCl:Gly (1:2), and ChCh:Gly:AlCl3 (1:4:0.33) showed the best pretreatment performances, which were ascribed to the ability of the DESs to selectively cleave ether bonds while keeping C–C linkages intact. Further experiments varying other parameters were carried out using ChCl:MEA (1:6). The pretreatment temperatures and times tested were 80, 100, and 120 °C for 3, 6, and 9 h. The results indicated pretreatment with ChCl:MEA at a temperature of 120 °C for 3 h to achieve the lowest lignin content (8.95% ± 0.15%), with a cellulose recovery of 70.17% ± 0.20%. These findings were attributed to the fact that heating during the pretreatment process can break the ether bonds between lignin and carbohydrates, allowing more lignin to dissolve in the DES. The effect of the substrate-to-DES ratio was also studied, with ratios of 1:8, 1:12, 1:16, 1:20, and 1:24. Generally, using more biomass improves process efficiency due to there being a larger quantity present in the reaction system, therefore more biomass content is more favorable. However, a high substrate to DES solution ratio results in accumulation of solid particles due to the high viscosity, whereas a low substrate to DES solution ratio can result in more breaking of ether bonds and minimal removal of lignin. The authors found that a substrate to DES solution ratio of 1:12 was optimal for achieving a low lignin content and high cellulose content. All told, pretreatment with ChCl:MEA (1:6) at 120 °C for 3 h with a substrate to DES solution ratio of 1:12 was determined to be optimal for sugarcane leaves. The pretreated samples were then subjected to enzymatic hydrolysis using a cellulolytic consortium, following which higher reducing sugar contents were observed for the DES-treated samples compared to untreated sugarcane leaves. This was attributed to the removal of complex structure during DES pretreatment. Finally, hydrogen generation was carried out in a simultaneous saccharification and fermentation process with a substrate loading of 4 g volatile solids, from which the highest total production (3187 ± 202 mL L−1) and production rate (317.5 ± 20.5 mL L−1 d −1) were obtained with DES-pretreated sugarcane leaves. 4.2 DESs for extraction of bioactive compounds A ChCl and ascorbic acid (2:1) DES was used as a solvent to extract phenolic compounds (i.e., phytochemicals) from coconut shells, namely 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylic acid, 1,2-dimethyl ester, 2-nonaprenyl-6-methoxyphenol, 2′,6′-bis(trimethylsiloxy)-acetophenone, and tri-methyl[4-(1,1,3,3,-tetramethylbutyl)phenoxy]silane. Those compounds were then employed as reducing agents in the fabrication of iron nanoparticles (Fe3O4) via the hydrothermal method [153]. The obtained nanoparticles were not uniform and had spherical and rod-like shapes; their uneven dispersity was attributed to the non-optimized synthesis and operational conditions (e.g., the ratio of iron precursors, the type of base used, mixing temperature, agitation, and pH). Many other studies pertaining to the synthesis of organic and inorganic nanoparticles have confirmed that DESs can be pivotal in shaping nanoparticles [20,21]. More recently, DESs have been reported to dramatically influence the shape of precipitated crystals of active pharmaceutical ingredients [154]. In the reviewed study, the prepared nanoparticles were added to a bacteria medium obtained from palm oil mill effluent sludge for biohydrogen generation. The hydrogen yield obtained using this method was 11.11 mLH2 g−1sugar, which is significantly lower than in other studies that used the same magnetic iron nanoparticles synthesized by other methods [155–158]. This indicates that the synthesis route is of paramount importance in determining biohydrogen yield. Investigating other DES formulations is highly recommended as selection of the most appropriate composition can lead to better results. It is well-established that DESs can significantly improve the dispersibility of nanomaterials and re-engineer their surface chemistry [159,160]. 4.3 DESs for extraction of fermentation inhibitors In a study by Makoś et al. [161], DESs were used to remove the fermentation inhibitors generated during hydrolysis, such as furfural (FF) and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). The presence of FF and HMF confers many disadvantages including, but not limited to, inhibiting cell growth and minimizing the amount of biofuels generated. Hydrophobic DESs composed of ± camphor (C) acting as the HBA and 1-decanol (DOL), decanoic acid (DecAc), or 3,4-xylenol (Xyl) as the HBD were prepared in a molar ratio of 1:2. Extraction was carried out by mixing each prepared DES with synthetic hydrolysates, incubating with continuous stirring, and then pH neutralizing. Initial results revealed the C:Xyl DES to have the lowest extraction efficiency, while the C:DOL DES had the highest. These results were attributed to the high water solubility and viscosity of C:Xyl, which limited its extraction ability. It is worth noting that the efficiency increased with DES hydrophobicity. The C:DOL DES was selected for further experiments, and was recycled using activated carbon as an adsorbent for FF and HMF. The recycled DES showed slightly lower efficiency in comparison to the fresh DES, but could be actively recycled up to 12 times. Beyond FF and HMF, other fermentation inhibitors (e.g., phenols and organic acids) are present in real hydrolysates and may also be extractable with a DES. As such, further investigation of the simultaneous extraction of fermentation inhibitors is recommended. Table S4 compares the single-stage extraction efficiency results obtained from studies utilizing different extraction solvents, including other DESs, with those of the proposed DES (i.e., C:DOL). Ultimately, C:DOL is considered a promising alternative extractive solvent due to its low cost and green nature. 5 DESs in fuel cells Hydrogen is not only considered an alternative to carbon-based fuels but is viewed as the fuel of the future since it can be used in highly-efficient power generation systems, including fuel cells for both vehicle transportation and decentralized electricity production [11]. A fuel cell is a device that converts chemical energy into electrical energy, or converts various types of fuels, such as hydrogen (or hydrogen-rich fuel), methanol, natural gas, or any other hydrocarbon, into electrical power via a low-temperature electrochemical process. Fuel cells are currently emerging as alternatives to the engines conventionally employed in both vehicles and stationary distributed energy systems. Using hydrogen in fuel cells can eliminate emissions by allowing the fuel cell to operate at lower temperatures. Within the fuel cell, the proton exchange membrane is a critical component since it highly influences overall performance of the cell. In this context, polymer electrolyte membranes (PEMs) have been proposed as a promising category of proton exchange membrane, with a number of polymers having been investigated, including the conventionally used perfluorinated polymers. Among perfluorinated polymers, Nafion is renowned as the top choice for fuel cells owing to its durability, physical and chemical characteristics, and proton-conducting capabilities [162]. It is worth noting that in Nafion, ionic clusters expand when exposed to moisture, creating interconnected pathways for diffusion. Additionally, under high operating temperatures, Nafion suffers from water loss and associated collapse of those ionic clusters, which leads to decreased proton conductivity. Addressing this drawback is an important area of investigation. DESs can fulfill individual or multiple simultaneous roles in fuel cell components. Especially, they can act as eutectic electrolytes to enhance mass transfer and as catalyst enhancers to facilitate electrochemical reactions [163,164], and are proposed as electrolytes for proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells due to their proton dissociation capability and low viscosity. For instance, a DES with N,N,N-trimethylpropylsulphonate ammonium hydrosulfate and urea acting as the HBA and HBD, respectively, was prepared at three different molar ratios (2:1, 1:1, and 1:2) and then used as the electrolyte in fuel cells by Xu et al. [165]. Nafion membranes were soaked in the DES samples at a temperature of 70 °C for 48 h, then sandwiched between Pt/C electrodes in cells (Fig. 10 a). When the DES molar ratio was 1:1, the fuel cell peak power density reached 92.5 mW cm−2 at 50 °C, a value significantly higher than that obtained using the HBA alone (48.5 mW cm−2), a difference attributed to enhancement of hydrogen ion transfer by the well-structured hydrogen bonding between the DES components. Meanwhile, increasing the HBD fraction resulted in a significant decrease of peak power density, to 21.4 mW cm−2, due to steric hinderance that influenced proton transfer. This result indicates that the HBD fraction in the DES has a substantial impact on power density and overall fuel cell performance efficiency. Evaluation of the electrochemical window (EW) of cells with different electrolytes (Fig. 10b) showed the HBD to not play any role in EW stability; however, a slight negative potential shift was observed with increasing HBD fraction. Overall, EW values in the presence of DESs were within the range of 0–1.23 V, supporting potential use in fuel cells. It is recommended to extend this research by evaluating the DES uptake and swelling of the membrane to elucidate potential the mechanism pathways. The same group developed another DES and evaluated its performance as an electrolyte for fuel cell applications [166]. This DES was prepared from N,N,N-trimethylbutylsulphonate ammonium hydrosulfate mixed with urea in three different molar ratios (2:1, 1:1, and 1:2). A similar procedure was followed for evaluating cell performance, in which the DES with a molar ratio of 2:1 displayed the highest performance, attaining a peak power density of 80.2 mW cm−2 at a temperature of 50 °C. The results obtained are summarized in Table 7 . In another work carried out by Karimi et al. [167], DESs composed of NaI:EG in different molar ratios were likewise evaluated for use as electrolytes with polymeric (Nafion) membranes in PEM fuel cells. The rheological and thermal properties of the prepared DESs were evaluated, as well as their impact on Nafion conduction properties and overall cell performance. Additionally, the DES uptake and swelling of Nafion 115® was evaluated. Altering the DES molar ratio was found to significantly reduce overall uptake, thereby controlling diffusion pathways, proton conductivity, and membrane mechanical stability. Based on rheological and thermal properties, NaI:EG (1:10) was selected for use in fuel cell performance testing. The overall fuel cell performance obtained under anhydrous conditions was significantly higher than previously reported results using IL-based electrolytes. In fact, a cell using NaI:EG (1:10) DES as the electrolyte was able to provide superior performance at 95 °C compared to pristine Nafion. Nonetheless, the cell using water with Nafion showed enhanced performance, hence it remains desirable to develop new DESs capable of surpassing fuel cells with water-based Nafion membranes. Fig. 11 depicts DES interaction with Nafion matrix parts. The DES was postulated to be present in amorphous phase Nafion near the sulfonic acid functional groups, and possibly permeated the ionic clusters. The XRD results indicate that greater EG content may lead to noticeable intensity reductions in peaks from the amorphous phase of Nafion, and hence to peak broadening. These findings imply that the DES tends to interact more with the amorphous phase than the crystalline phase of Nafion. Future dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) is proposed for the verification and better understanding of this interaction. Interestingly, the authors also explained in detail the mechanism of proton conduction in a DES-based membrane by calculating the activation energy, and also by considering pKa. Proton conduction was ascribed to both the vehicular mechanism and the Grotthuss mechanism. The vehicular mechanism occurred due to protonation of hydroxyl groups in EG molecules; in this mechanism, proton conduction can be boosted through increasing DES uptake by Nafion. However, excessive DES uptake may lead to increased fuel crossover through the membrane and hence reduce its mechanical stability. Meanwhile, the Grotthuss mechanism occurred due to sulfonic groups within polymer side chains and the presence of halide salt anions. There is also room to explore further possible mechanisms including proton conduction by proton hopping between hydroxyl groups, sulfonic acid, and I - , and between - SO 3 - functional groups, EG, and I - . Additionally, the diffusion pathways within the polymer matrix and the DES surface tension can substantially influence proton conduction. Overall, it is evident that DES presence within Nafion can lead to superior proton conduction. This can be ascribed to the electronegativity of the DES; Na + has low electronegativity, while I - is an electronegative anion with a large surface area, and hence I - may serve as an active spot for proton hopping in this system. The same group of authors also examined the use of NaBr:EG DESs in different molar ratios as electrolytes for fuel cells [168,169]. According to the mechanism proposed, and in accordance with their earlier study, hydrogen bonding between the HBA and HBD enables the DES to promote proton conduction. That is, the halide anion, being highly electronegative and the core of DES hydrogen bonding, acts as a proton hopping site. Furthermore, the halide ion has the tendency to architect the arrangement of surrounding hydroxyl groups. Also, the nearby presence of sulfonic acid groups (i.e., ionic clusters) could result in proton conduction over interconnected networks. Hence, in DES-saturated Nafion membranes, three main aspects should be investigated to understand proton conduction: electronegativity of halide anion sites, Nafion ionic clusters, and HBD hydroxyl groups. All told, the design of any fuel cell electrolyte utilizing a DES should feature with the following: • Low cost • High proton and electrical conductivity • High thermal and electrochemical stability • Low viscosity • Inflammability and negligible vapor pressure • Wide electrochemical window • Device compatibility and non-corrosivity • Biocompatibility and biodegradability • Recyclability • Controllable degrees of hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity Regarding the implications of utilizing DESs as fuel cell catalysts, these mixtures promise to improve catalyst support materials, nanoscale structuring, surface chemistry modification, and development of low-cost and abundant-material-based catalysts; they also have potential to prolong lifespan and mitigate degradation [20,21,117,170–173]. The use of DESs in functionalization of nanomaterials is another promising area for investigation. Fig. 12 shows the different types of carbonaceous nanomaterials that can be used to electrocatalyze PEM fuel cells. In this context, DESs have been reported to modify the surface chemistry of CNTs and graphene [21,159,160]. DESs also can be explored as antifreeze agents to extend the durability of PEM fuel cells in cold weather. For instance, NADESs have been validated to cryopreserve animals at extreme temperature amplitudes [175–177]. Finally, the potential applications of DESs can be extended to other types of fuel cells, such as alkaline, solid oxide, molten carbonate, phosphoric acid, and direct methanol fuel cells. 6 Limitations, challenges, and prospects The hydrogen color spectrum has yet to be standardized despite a common agreement on the main hydrogen production routes (e.g., green, blue, and grey), with many contradictory and confusing terminologies and color codes currently in use. Addressing this issue is imperative for pushing forward the hydrogen economy. Green hydrogen is primarily generated from renewable feedstocks and using renewable energy resources, and utilizing DESs in such processes promises to realize more sustainable technologies. However, all studies dedicated to the use of DESs to date have solely focused on the use of renewable feedstocks in green hydrogen generation. In particular, DESs have been employed to generate green hydrogen via electrocatalysis and photocatalysis of water splitting and urea-assisted water splitting, and through fermentation of biomass extracts. However, this research area is not yet mature, and according to the TRL, there remains a lot of development to be completed concerning DES utilization in these technologies. For example, in many studies, the specific role of the DES was not clearly identified, nor in some cases even discussed. This makes it challenging to interpret the results obtained. The basic question that should be addressed in each individual study is ‘how has DES incorporation influenced the process?’ Also, two main measures are frequently overlooked in studies involving DESs, namely the carbon footprint and water footprint. To assess whether DESs do in fact provide a more sustainable approach, it is necessary to employ essential key lifecycle assessment metrics, such as global warming potential. Economic feasibility is another essential aspect that needs to be addressed. The role of a DES in a particular green hydrogen generation technology can be classified as either primary or secondary, where primary means the DES directly influences the efficiency of green hydrogen generation, and secondary that it offers an indirect enhancement to the overall generation process. Elucidating and classifying those impacts will contribute to understanding the ultimate utility of a DES and can provide a crystal-clear indication whether it will add value to the process. The majority of studies to date have involved DESs in the preparation of electrocatalysts and photocatalysts, which counts as a secondary role. Notably, some of the reported results were not promising, but this can be attributed to the improper selection of DES formulations, or to not optimizing the conditions. Therefore, systematic criteria should be developed for the selection of a DES composition and the corresponding molar ratio. This can be extended to the exploration of binary or ternary DES systems. In addition, better understanding of DES roles would make it more feasible to compare DES mixtures with their respective chief ingredients and other conventional agents. Only a very limited number of studies have discussed the mechanisms and kinetics of DES effects on hydrogen production; therefore, mechanism pathways and reaction kinetics should be further explored. Moreover, comprehending microbial and enzymatic interactions with DESs is of paramount importance for leveraging them in biohydrogen production. It is also worth noting that to identify the best technology for producing green hydrogen, a number of factors need be considered including the required energy intensity, energy source, by-products, technology complexity, cost, and yield. Therefore, more effort should be invested in unraveling the potential uses of DESs in the green hydrogen value chain, and across different scales (e.g., cell and stack). For instance, there have been extensive efforts to study the incorporation of DESs in various technologies for treatment and purification of water and wastewater. That would be another area to explore in the context of hydrogen production, as the water must be purified and deionized prior to electrolysis. Yet, it is also important to explore other abundant feedstock sources, such as direct use of seawater and wastewater. This ultimately can improve the energy-water nexus. Likewise, in the field of fuel cell applications, only a few articles dedicated to the use of DESs have been published so far. It behooves the scientific community to pay more attention to this substantive research area. Notably, while DESs can modify membranes and electrodes in beneficial ways, screening 106 possible DES formulations might be challenging. Using in silico methods to identify the most potential candidates will reduce time, effort, and cost significantly. It is also imperative to employ LCA to gauge the carbon footprint of methods involving DESs. In general, several parameters should be considered to assess how DESs are beneficial to fuel cells, including FC lifespan and infrastructure, fuel consumption, power efficiency, and overall performance. It would therefore be extremely beneficial to conduct a Well-To-Wheel analysis with incorporation of DESs at various stages. The expected outcomes from implementing DESs in fuel cells are elevated hydrogen exchange capacity, increased lifetime and durability, greater power density, improved efficiency, and reduced cost, all of which ultimately render the fuel cells greener and more sustainable. While green hydrogen is being produced through the HER, green oxygen is simultaneously produced through the OER. This oxygen can be utilized in numerous redox applications, in which DESs can play a variety of roles such as media and modifiers of catalysts. This signifies synergy and potential industrial symbiosis. 7 Conclusions There is an ongoing transition towards the utilization of renewable energy sources to achieve a sustainable energy landscape and net zero emission goal. In this context, renewable green hydrogen can act as a 'game changer'. However, it is important to acknowledge that the production methods are not entirely environmentally friendly, as they often involve use of carbon-emitting agents. This hinders the transition into sustainable hydrogen economy and a carbon–neutral future. On the other hand, deep eutectic solvents are considered safe, green, and efficient multi-task agents for green hydrogen technologies, and have contributed significant developments in enhancing the overall efficiency of hydrogen generation and fuel cells. This comprehensive systematic review article delves into the production of green hydrogen with DESs employed in various phases of the generation process. The SUST (Synthesizable, Upgradable, Storable, and Treatable) value chain framework of DESs was introduced. DESs have the versatility to serve multiple functions, including acting as a solvent, electrolyte, or precursor, facilitating colloidal suspension and serving as a reaction medium. They also play roles in processes like galvanic replacement, shape control, and decoration, and can serve as extractive agents and even oxidants. The prospective utility of DES systems should be extended to encompass other hydrogen technologies, including both light-dependent methods (e.g., photo-fermentation, photo-electrochemical cells, and microbial photoelectrochemical cells) and light-independent approaches (e.g., microbial electrocatalysis cells). In summary, integrating DESs into green hydrogen production can transform it into super green hydrogen. This represents a promising avenue of research for improving related technologies and achieving sustainable development goals. Raiyan Al-Farsi obtained her BEng degree in Chemical Engineering with honors and a First-Class degree from Aston University in 2022. In the same year, Raiyan joined the Green Research Group led by Prof. Maan Hayyan as a research assistant. Since then, she has been actively involved in various research projects, including applications of deep eutectic solvents in green hydrogen and nanofluid energy storage. Specializing in renewable energy, her focus spans green hydrogen, sustainability, and eco-friendly solvents. Raiyan is also a dedicated analyst in the National Carbon Neutrality Program in the Sultanate of Oman, embodying her commitment to practical applications of sustainable solutions. Maan Hayyan received his B.Sc. and M.Sc. degrees in Chemical Engineering from the University of Technology—Baghdad in 2004 and 2006, respectively. He then earned his Ph.D. degree with Distinction from the University of Malaya in 2012. Prof. Maan is the leader and founder of the Green Research Group. Additionally, he is the co-founder/founder of the BEng Chemical Engineering, BEng Energy Engineering, MSc Renewable Energy Engineering, and MSc Sustainable Energy Development and Management programs at Muscat University. Recognized as one of the pioneering researchers in green engineering, with a specific emphasis on deep eutectic solvents and ionic liquids, he has been listed among the world's top 2% scientists, according to the Stanford University-Elsevier database, in the disciplines of chemical engineering and energy engineering, based on both single-year and career-long data. Prof. Maan holds 11 filed and granted patents and has authored over 100 peer-reviewed journal publications. He has served as a peer-reviewer for more than 100 SCIE indexed journals. Furthermore, he has been awarded many gold medals from international exhibitions for his outstanding contributions to research and innovation.

coredata.dc:description: While reliance on renewable energy resources has become a reality, there is still a need to deploy greener and more sustainable methods in order to achieve sustainable development goals. Indeed, green hydrogen is currently believed to be a reliable solution for global warming and the pollution challenges arising from fossil fuels, making it the resilient fuel of the future. However, the sustainability of green hydrogen technologies is yet to be achieved. In this context, generation of green hydrogen with the aid of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as green mixtures has been demonstrated as a promising research area. This systematic review article covers green hydrogen generation through water splitting and biomass fermentation when DESs are utilized within the generation process. It also discusses the incorporation of DESs in fuel cell technologies. DESs can play a variety of roles such as solvent, electrolyte, or precursor; colloidal suspension and reaction medium; galvanic replacement, shape-controlling, decoration, or extractive agent; finally oxidant. These roles are relevant to several methods of green hydrogen generation, including electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and fermentation. As such, it is of utmost importance to screen potential DES formulations and determine how they can function in and contribute throughout the green hydrogen mobility stages. The realization of super green hydrogen generation stands out as a pivotal milestone in our journey towards achieving a more sustainable form of development; DESs have great potential in making this milestone achievable. Overall, incorporating DESs in hydrogen generation constitutes a promising research area and offers potential scalability for green hydrogen production, storage, transport, and utilization.
